Since both the Tokaido Road and the Hosando Road (later called the Nakasendo Road) both passed through the Osaka Gate, it was an important centre of transportation.

sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。Both を一箇所削除しました。

sen.j: その重要性は、平安時代中期（810年）以後には、三関の一つとなっていた事からも見てとれる。

The other two major gates were Fuwa Gate and Suzuka Gate, with Arachi Gate being the third until the early Heian period.

sen.j: しかし、逢坂二丁目の長安寺付近にあった関寺と逢坂関を関連付ける記述が更級日記や石山寺縁起に見られる事などから同寺の付近にあったと見られる。
sen.e: However it is presumed that Osaka no-seki checking station used to locate near Choan-ji Temple station, since there is a related record of Seki-dera Temple, which used to be close to Choan-ji Temple of Osaka 2-chome, and Osaka bo-seki station in Sarashina Nikki (Sarashina Diary) and Ishiyama-dera Engi. (a scroll painting of the history of Ishiyama-dera Temple)

However, from descriptions of relations between Seki-dera Temple, which stood near Choan-ji Temple in Osaka 2-chome, and Osaka Gate recorded in the Sarashina Nikki (Sarashina Diary) and the Ishiyama-dera Records, it is presumed that the gate was located near Choan-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: Reworded sentence for accuracy, spelling, clarity- I think the "同寺の付近" refers to Seki-dera, not Choan-ji, but since they were close to each other, I left it as Choan-ji
sen.e: However, from descriptions of relations between Seki-dera Temple, which stood near Choan-ji Temple in Osaka 2-chome, and Osaka no seki recorded in the Sarashina Nikki (Sarashina Diary) and the Ishiyama-dera Records, it is presumed that the barrier was located near Choan-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: barrier としました。

There is also a monument inscribed "Site of Osakayama Gate" beside the Osakayama Checkpoint (to the east of Otani Station on the Keihan-Keishin Line), which is located on the side of National Route 1 in Otani-cho, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 寛平7年（895年）12月3日_(旧暦)（12月26日）の太政官符では「五位以上及孫王」が畿内を出ることを禁じており、この中で会坂関を畿内の東端と定義している。
sen.e: In the Daijokanpu (official documents issued by Daijokan, Grand Council of State) issued on December 3, 895 (December 26, according to the old lunisolar calendar), People higher than goi (Fifth Rank) in the rank or Son-o were forbidden to go outside Kinai (territories in the vicinity of the capital and under direct imperial rule; (in Japanese history) the five kuni in the immediate vicinity of Kyoto), in this documents, Osaka no-seki was defined as the east end of Kinai.
sen.cmt: 五位以上及孫王 - 定訳不明
sen.e: In the Daijokanpu (official documents of the Daijokan, Grand Council of State) issued on December 3, 895 (December 26, according to the old lunisolar calendar), people holding the fifth rank or higher and relatives of the Emperor were forbidden to go outside Kinai, which included Kyoto and the surrounding territories, with the east end of Kinai being defined as Osaka Gate.
sen.cmt: "issued by"→"of the"Deleted space"People higher than goi (Fifth Rank) in the rank or Son-o"→"people holding the fifth rank or higher and relatives of the Emperor"Deleted spaceAdded "the""(territories in the vicinity of the capital and under direct imperial rule; (in Japanese history) the five kuni in the immediate vicinity of Kyoto)"→", which included Kyoto and the surrounding territories""in this documents,"→"with""Osaka no-seki was defined as"→"being defined as Osaka Gate" and moved
sen.e: In the Daijokanpu (official documents of the Daijokan, Grand Council of State) issued on December 3, 895, people holding the fifth rank or higher and relatives of the Emperor were forbidden to go out of the Kinai region and Osaka no seki was considered as the east boundary.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 関はやがて旅人の休憩所としての役割なども果すようになり、天禄元年（970年）には藤原道綱母が逢坂越を通った際に休息した事が蜻蛉日記に記されている。
sen.e: The checking point soon became the rest station for travelers, there was a record in Kagero Nikki (The Gossamer Years) that mother of FUJIWARA no Michitsuna passed Osaka goe mountain pass and rested in 970.
The gate soon became a rest station for travelers, and FUJIWARA no Micitsuna's mother, the author of Kagero Nikki (The Gossamer Years), records resting there in 907 while crossing the Osaka Pass.

sen.e: The barrier soon became a rest station for travelers, and FUJIWARA no Michitsuna's mother, the author of Kagero Nikki (The Gossamer Years), records resting there in 970 while crossing the Osaka Pass.

sen.j: 逢坂関は鎌倉時代以降も京都の東の要衝として機能し、南北朝時代_(日本)以降には園城寺が支配して関銭が徴収されるようになった。
sen.e: Osaka no-seki checking station functioned as an important point on the east of Kyoto after the Kamakura period, it was run by Enjo-ji Temple after the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), and sekisen (toll) was started to be collected.

From the Kamakura Period, Osaka Gate held a strategically important position to the East of Kyoto, and starting in the Northern and Southern Courts Period, it was managed by Enjo-ji Temple, which began charging a toll.
sen.cmt: Reworded sentence
sen.e: From the Kamakura period, Osaka no seki held a strategically important position to the east of Kyoto, and starting in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), it was managed by Enjo-ji Temple, which began charging a toll.
sen.cmt: (Japan)を追加しました。

sen.j: しかし、貞治6年（1367年）に園城寺の衆徒が南禅寺所轄の関を破却したため、侍所頭人の今川貞世によって四宮川原関や松坂峠関（ともに現・京都市山科区）とともに焼払われた。
sen.e: However after the monk-soldiers of Enjo-ji Temple destroyed the checking station, which was jurisdiction of Nanzen-ji Temple, Osaka no-seki checking station was burned down by Sadayo IMAGAWA, Samurai-dokoro tonin (Governor of the Board of Retainers), together with Shinomiyagawara-seki checking station and Matsuzakatoge-seki checking station. (both are currently at Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City)

sen.e: However after the warrior monks of Enjo-ji Temple destroyed the pass under the jurisdiction of Nanzen-ji Temple in 1367, Osaka no seki and Shugu-kawara no seki (both in Yamashina Ward, Kyoto) were burned down by Sadayo IMAGAWA, the Samurai-dokoro tonin (Governor of the Board of Retainers).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: その後、逢坂関は再設されたが、寛正元年（1460年）に伊勢神宮造替のために大津に新関が設置された際には、大谷・逢坂の両関が一時廃されており、経済上の理由から室町幕府が園城寺の関を支配下に置こうとしたと考えられる。
sen.e: After above incident Osaka no-seki station was re-built, however both Otani and Osaka checking station were temporally abolished when there was new checking station was built in Otsu, due to reconstruction of Ise-jingu Shrine, it is presumed Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) tried to have checking station of Enjo-ji Temple under their control for financial reasons.

After the above incident, Osaka Gate was re-built but was temporarily abolished along with Otani Gate when, due to the reconstruction of Ise-jingu Shrine, a new gate was built in Otsu, and it is believed the Muromachi Shogunate tried to bring the gaten of Enjo-ji Temple under their control for financial reasons.

sen.e: After the above incident, Osaka no seki was rebuilt but was temporarily no used along with Otani no seki (Otani Barrier) when a new pass was built in Otsu for the reconstruction of Ise-jingu Shrine in 1460 and it is believed that the Muromachi bakufu wanted to gain control of the pass under the jurisdiction of Enjoj-ji Temple for financial reasons.
